displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And, uh- (Sound Door opens) Patient: Right. Doctor: And within the apricot seeds, there’s a compound that can be converted. The downfall of the idea, so, scientifically, was actually kind of an interesting idea. But the downfall is humans don’t have the enzyme to convert the thing to cyanide. So it was never going to work because we just don’t have the enzyme. So it, so they did a lot of things, and patients went to Mexico, and they did this. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Uh, and it didn’t really have any success. What your, you’re showing me something else. I don’t know anything about vitamin B-seventeen. I didn’t know there was a B-seventeen. Patient: Yes. I know. No, nobody knows. Doctor: And so whether that’s anything that, I, I don’t know anything about that, so I can’t really tell you- Patient: Yeah. I know you don’t know about vitamins. Doctor: But that’s what the apricot seed was. Now I don’t know if they got a bunch of apricot seed ground up later on, and going, hey, we’ve got to get rid of this. Let’s go with a different story. Doctor: Uh, that would be one of my worries with all this kind of stuff. Patient: Yeah. Right. Doctor: So whenever I hear we’re going to go down to Mexico-

Patient: Well I got a… Doctor: But you don’t want to. Patient: I got to address that. I got to address that and… Doctor: All the more reason to do surgery if it holds up your paddleball and all that stuff right? Patient: Well maybe, yeah, right. Family Member: Well what the – will that lesions – his legs are really weak and they hurt. Would that lesion? Patient: It’s not bad is it? Doctor: I mean I don’t think it’s worse, but it’s not getting better. Family Member: So would that lesion affect his legs also, is it the same stem you know nerve system? Doctor: You know usually not. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because I mean hopefully – the arm nerves are on the outside. Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Yeah. Now will that show if there was any problem or would it? Doctor: Well – Family Member: I know MRI show more. Doctor: Well they both can show that. I think it’s more of what are we looking for to do with that. Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: He’s sort of past that. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: It’s not a great utility for us at this moment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But sometimes if we find that it’s useful later we certainly can. Yeah. Family Member: Now do you think after three months, after he’s on medication, what scans will you be taking? Will you be taking like the - Doctor: The CAT scan.

Patient: No pain. There’s just a little; I know my right hip is there. You know I know what the sensation is. Doctor: So the radiation helped? Patient: Yes, I think so, yes. Doctor: But you still need to take the opioids. Patient: Yeah, yeah, but not as much. I’ve cut down. Doctor: So the OxyContin was two times a day and now you’re once a day. Patient: Uh sometimes none a day. Family Member: Yes. Patient: Oh OxyContin, once a day. Yes, you know I was taking the ten milligrams maybe twice a day and then once a day. And if it’s acting up a little bit in the morning well then the OxyContin, I’ll take that. But it’s not every day. As far as staying ahead of the pain then stop the pain. Doctor: You said you move your bowels. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. And uh how’s your appetite?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: I could eat nothing for about, about at least about two days. Doctor: Okay so let me send me over to chemo. Okay? We’ll do the chemo today, but meanwhile I’m going to call our radiologist and see if they can tell me something about the CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then I’ll come over there and talk to you about it. Patient: Let me ask you something, let me ask you something Dr. B____. What is what is better, CAT scan or ah MRI? Doctor: It depends on what part of the body we’re looking at. But a CAT scan is pretty good, it’s a pretty good test. If we don’t find something or need to look at it more. Patient: You said it’s not showing on the… Doctor: Well not when we looked quickly, but uh you know we need a radiologists when – that’s why we have that specialty who reads CAT scans. Okay and I’m not one. (laughs) Patient: Yeah, I get it. Doctor: Okay, So as I get things… Patient: I’m gonna wait here until you get back. Cause, definitely how I’m tired and I’m gonna lay down man. Doctor: Yeah, okay. So as we get things sorted out I will come over and talk to you. Patient: Do I have to get any more shots today?

Patient: I know. I know it. Doctor: It’s fixing the fungal infection then just to wait until it comes right back. Patient: I agree. Doctor: So… Patient: Well. Doctor: Do you want to see a urologist here today? Family Member: That’s what I told him – yeah. Doctor: Let me ask. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because we have Dr. Lucas here and … Family Member: Okay. Patient: The last urologist I went to back home I walked out because I sat there for two hours and I’m out of here. Family Member: Every time you go there I mean you can’t get in to see him. I mean you’re there for hours.

Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - um that the side effects from the hormone therapies were getting a little bit too much for you. Patient: Yes. Doctor: And your preference, which I agreed with at the time, was to stop the Lupron you get. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And given that your PSA level is very low, it was an investment point level, that you basically stop that, allow the testosterone to recover if you did good by itself, and then to monitor the PSA to see where that was at. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So on the one hand, it does move over time, if the testosterone continues to increase, which it probably will, may feed the cancer. But on the other hand, in the meantime, your quality of life should be better than it would have been with a testosterone let’s say less than twenty. Patient: Okay. That’s’ Doctor: So it’s kind of the choice that we made, and this is sort of the natural expectation of what we were expecting to see. Patient: You would recommend having it done Doc? Doctor: No. There’s no evidence that people like you that people like you in controlling cancer. Patient: You know I was reading an article a while back that I like about it’s going to become common for folks to live into their hundreds.

Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: So nobody goes in? Patient: Not unless they have to pick up something. They can't stay because there's not air conditioning. The HVAC is turned off. Doctor: Holy mackerel that’s like serious. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you think you guys will ever go back someday? Hard to say? Patient: It’ll go back someday. Doctor: Mm. Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: Anywho! Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, here's where we are. Your PSA is six something- Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: it would not be a good idea. His doctor took him off. His primary care doctor Doctor: Mm Hmm. Family Member: before all this treatment even started. Doctor: Really? Family Member: She was like… Doctor: Well now that his kidney function is improving, we may be able to restart it if your sugars keep on being high. Okay so next time what I’m gonna suggest is that we get fasting bloodwork Family Member: Okay. Doctor: and see where things are at. Okay? That way I’ll be able to see if we need to put you back on the medication. Family Member: I think that’s a good idea. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But that’s not a crutch either to say I’m back on Metformin I can eat cookies. Patient: Oh, oh…

Patient: Yes. Doctor: You can’t see it on scan. Patient: I’ve been, I’ve been dealing, I’ve been dealing with it for… Doctor: Okay. Patient: But it’s got to be something Dr. B____ because it wouldn’t be hard. I have not felt, I have never felt that before. Doctor: Okay. So let me… Patient: And then it feels so funny man like… Doctor: Okay, I got it. Let me have gastroenterology see you because they may need to scope you both down below as well as in the stomach, okay? First of all because your diarrhea is not something that’s typically happens with this chemotherapy. Okay so we need to get to the bottom of what’s causing you diarrhea also. Alright? Patient: Right. That’s the - that’s the thing that they, man, I can eat, I can eat, but. Doctor: Okay. I got that. Patient: I couldn’t eat nothing. Doctor: But you could not… Patient: I could eat nothing for about, about at least about two days.

Patient: Is this something that’s possible. Doctor: When we do a scan it only tells us after you have X amount of tumors or cells that have glommed together how big it is. Patient: Mhmm, mhmm. Yep. Doctor: Right? So I can only report out what I see, but if I were to open you up || like that… Patient: Yep. Doctor: …it would show more… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …and it would show probably very small areas. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and those are non-targetable. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that’s just the – the struggle is unless that thing whichever one decides to block anything off… Patient: Mhmm.

Healthcare Professional: Like the timing? Of the course -- Patient: No, the, eh, um. The aches and pains, I got a bunch of them. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Patient: Just, more -- But like the ridges on the nailbeds. ‘Cuz if I, if I notice something that is abnormal and say, “MMmmm.” I’m gonna make a phone call. But that’s gonna just doesn’t make sense. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. In your consent, it has adverse things to expect, what are more common, what are less common. It’s in your consent. Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: So, it’s in there. I’m supposed to go over it with ya. You know, then you have people like T_, myself, C_ as resources, to just say, “Hey, you know, my nails - It could be that every time I’m getting chemo, things stop growing.” And then once the chemo is out of your body, it starts growing, so you’re gonna get ridges. Family Member: Ohhh. Doctor: So, you can sorta like. Doctor: Exactly. So, you’ll sorta know those sorts of things. Family Member: Wow.

Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer. Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of those drugs block the DNA in certain ways, but in the virus, mostly. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And some of them block enzymes that the virus makes. And I think those things may also block cancer enzymes, is what they-

Patient: No discomfort. Tired. Doctor: And any chest pain, shortness of breath? Patient: No. Doctor: Have you had to go to the hospital for any reason since I last saw ya? Patient: No. Patient: No. Not, not hungry at all. Doctor: What’s your weight been doing? Patient: It’s, uh – two twelve -- Doctor: Two twelve. Patient: Today. Doctor: Is that up or down for you? Patient: It’s probably --

Patient: Everybody gets card, okay. Now is that here? Doctor: Yeah. So, there is a Dr. M____. We’re gonna write this down for you guys Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: and then we’ll make the referral but just so you know we’ll start the prior authorization process so by the time you see him we’ve got everything under way and then he’ll just take over. Patient: Okay and then I see you after or during? Doctor: Right, so like I’m kind of just hovering because we’re trying not to add more work. Patient: Okay. Doctor: He tells me every time you see him once a month because he draws blood work and everything so then I know you pop up in my systems like oh, you’re in the systems. So, if there’s issues though like things that aren’t going right and you feel whatever, you tell him but then you could always come back to see me anytime. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I’m just gonna put, I’m trying to think, am I giving you the shot or is that your neurologist? Who’s giving you the Lupron? Patient: You are. Doctor: So, you’d have to come back anyways. Did you get a shot today or are you coming?
